message_1:
Suppose P and Q are two propositions such that P is true and Q is false. Find the truth values of the following propositions:

a) (P ∧ Q)
b) (P ∨ Q)
c) (¬ P ∧ ¬ Q)
message_2:
Given that P is true and Q is false, we can determine the truth values of the given propositions as follows:

a) (P ∧ Q) - This proposition represents "P and Q." Since P is true and Q is false, the entire proposition is false because both parts need to be true for the "and" statement to be true.

b) (P ∨ Q) - This proposition represents "P or Q." Since P is true and Q is false, the entire proposition is true because only one part needs to be true for the "or" statement to be true.

c) (¬ P ∧ ¬ Q) - This proposition represents "not P and not Q." Since P is true, ¬ P is false. Since Q is false, ¬ Q is true. The entire proposition is false because both parts need to be true for the "and" statement to be true, but ¬ P is false.
